channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Blasts Reported at Nuclear Plant Seized by Russia
item.description: Artillery duels around a huge power plant on the Dnipro river raised the risk of an accident, as each side blamed the other for the explosions on Friday. The top Russian and U.S. diplomats said they were ready to discuss a deal to secure the release of the American basketball star Brittney Griner.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times

item.title: Israel Strikes Gaza as Tensions Rise
item.description: A senior figure of a Palestinian militant group was among 10 people killed in airstrikes that followed almost a week of rising tensions. Militants responded with a volley of rockets into Israel.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: A building damaged after an Israeli airstrike in Gaza City on Friday.

item.title: China Sends Ships and Planes Toward Taiwan Despite Rising Criticism
item.description: Beijing also halted talks with the United States on the military, climate change and other issues, sending ties between the two powers into a deeper chill.
item.dc:creator: Jane Perlez, Alexandra Stevenson, John Liu and Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taiwanese navy ships in Keelung, Taiwan, on Friday. Taiwan’s defense ministry said Chinese ships and planes crossed the informal median line in the Taiwan Strait on Friday.

item.title: Germany, Facing Energy Crisis, Gives Nuclear Another Look
item.description: For three decades, nuclear power was one of Germany’s most divisive debates. But with Russia cutting gas, Germans are revisiting their political energy taboos.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: The German village of Wattenbacherau, at the foot of the Isar 2 nuclear power plant.

item.title: Brittney Griner Is Sentenced to 9 Years in a Russian Penal Colony
item.description: President Biden called the sentence “unacceptable” and vowed to pursue all avenues to bring the American basketball star home. Her case has become mired in the conflict between Moscow and Washington over Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Brittney Griner was found guilty of drug charges by a Russian court on Thursday.

item.title: ‘Captain Condom’ Turned the Tide in Thailand’s War on AIDS and Overpopulation
item.description: At a time when most Thais avoided discussing safe sex and family planning, Mechai Viravaidya promoted condom use with spectacle and humor, saving millions of lives.
item.dc:creator: Seth Mydans
item.media:credit: Lauren DeCicca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Concerned that Thailand’s population was growing at an unsustainable pace, Mechai Viravaidya began promoting condom usage in the early 1970s, when few were willing to broach the subject.

item.title: France Faces ‘Most Severe’ Drought as Heat Persists in Europe
item.description: A lack of rain and a string of heat waves have caused devastating wildfires and left farmland parched in the country and much of the continent.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damage from wildfires at a campsite at the foot of Dune du Pilat, near Arcachon, France, in July. The prime minister urged people to be “very vigilant” about their water usage.

item.title: Beirut Port Silos Partly Collapse on Second Anniversary of Blast
item.description: The silos were damaged in the 2020 port explosion and government officials had warned that they could collapse.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: The smoldering remains of grain silos at the Port of Beirut, after a partial collapse on Thursday.

item.title: Sri Lankan Family Wins a Long Battle to Stay in Australia
item.description: Rights groups say they do not expect Australian immigration policy to change significantly with its new government, but the decision raised hopes for a more tolerant approach.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: The father of the family, Nadesalingam Murugappan, front, and the mother, Kokilapathmapriya Nadesalingam, embracing a supporter with a “Home Sweet Home” sign, arriving at an aerodrome near Biloela, Australia, in June.

item.title: Iran Targets Its Baha’i Community With Arrests and Home Demolitions
item.description: Representatives of the religious minority said that the crackdown was the latest chapter in a long history of persecution. The authorities accused those detained of being spies with links to Israel.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi

item.title: Thailand Nightclub Fire Kills at Least 13, Injures Dozens
item.description: Witnesses said the flames spread rapidly. A video showed victims running from the building with their clothes ablaze.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:description: The fire on Friday damaged the Mountain B pub in Chonburi Province. All of those who died were Thai citizens, according to the police.

item.title: Spain Limits Air-Conditioning to Save Energy
item.description: The country this week became the latest to announce restrictions, in part to promote energy efficiency but also to reduce consumption of Russian gas.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz and Daniel Victor
item.media:description: A thermometer displayed a temperature of 22.9 degrees Celsius (73 Fahrenheit) at a shopping mall in Madrid on Monday. The government announced that businesses cannot lower air conditioning below 27 Celsius (81 Fahrenheit) during the summer.

item.title: Mines, Fires, Rockets: The Ravages of War Bedevil Ukraine’s Farmers
item.description: A deal allowing ships to start carrying grain from Ukraine solved a logistical problem, but it left a more pressing one for Ukrainian farmers: growing and reaping crops in a war zone.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and David Guttenfelder
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the fields on a recent, sweltering afternoon during the harvest, flames crackled through the stubble of the recently harvested wheat crop of Vasily Tabachnyuk, picking up with gusts of wind.

item.title: Iran-U.S. Nuclear Negotiations Restart
item.description: Envoys from both countries gathered for another effort to restore the 2015 agreement to limit Tehran’s nuclear program. Expectations are low.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: Ali Bagheri Kani, front, Iran’s chief nuclear negotiator, in Vienna on Thursday. He said that the burden was on Washington to resuscitate the deal.

item.title: Chinese Military Drills Near Taiwan Continue
item.description: The live-fire military drills, which appear to be simulating an attack on the main island, have edged closer than ever before to territory Taiwan considers its own.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: A Chinese People’s Liberation Army aircraft flying over Pingtan Island, just across the strait from Taiwan, on Friday.

item.title: Ukrainian Grandmaster Bids to Unseat Russian Head of World Chess Body
item.description: Hoping to end Russia’s domination of the International Chess Federation, Andrii Baryshpolets is running for the presidency of the powerful governing organization.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Misha Friedman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Andrii Baryshpolets, a Ukrainian chess grandmaster, in Chennai, India, where he hopes to be elected president of the International Chess Federation this Sunday.

item.title: Why Australia’s Climate Bill Matters
item.description: After years of inaction, the world’s third largest exporter of fossil fuels decides to get serious about global warming
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times

item.title: U.S. and Russia Ready to Negotiate Griner’s Release
item.description: The countries’ top envoys made separate announcements after a meeting where they sat close together — without talking.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Neil MacFarquhar and Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and Sergei V. Lavrov, Russia’s foreign minister, at a meeting in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, on Friday.

item.title: Israel Hits Gaza, Prompting Rocket Barrage and Ending Relative Calm
item.description: In by far the biggest escalation of violence in Gaza since the end of a war in May 2021, Israeli airstrikes killed a militant leader and at least nine others, according to Palestinian officials.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Patrick Kingsley and Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: A building damaged after an Israeli airstrike in Gaza City on Friday.

item.title: Brittney Griner’s Sentence Renews Pressure on President Biden
item.description: The basketball star’s supporters are pressing for action. But critics of any possible deal are already fuming.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: After Brittney Griner’s sentence on Thursday, President Biden renewed his commitment to her release.

item.title: U.S. Warns African Countries That Buying Russian Oil Could Break Sanctions
item.description: “We caution countries not to break those sanctions,” the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, Linda Thomas-Greenfield said, warning of that they stood the chance “of having actions taken against them.”
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:description: The U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, Linda Thomas-Greenfield, in Accra, Ghana, on Friday. Most African countries have tried to stay out of Russia’s fight with Ukraine, have still suffered its consequences.

item.title: What I’m reading
item.description: The seismic shifts of the 1960s are still reverberating in the Democratic Party.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub

item.title: Coal vs. Wall Street
item.description: Republican state officials have found a new way to push back against “woke capitalism”— by punishing companies that distance themselves from fossil fuels.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Five major financial institutions, including BlackRock, were barred from doing business with West Virginia because the companies were distancing themselves from the coal industry.

item.title: U.S. Seeks to Reassure Asian Allies as China’s Military Grows Bolder
item.description: The Biden administration says its commitment to the region has only deepened, but critics say the tensions over Taiwan show that Washington needs stronger military and economic strategies.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Damien Cave
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken with the foreign ministers of Singapore and Vietnam during a meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, on Thursday. Mr. Blinken promised that the United States would stand by its allies.

item.title: Taiwan’s Generational Divide on China’s Threats
item.description: In areas close to the military drills, younger Taiwanese worried about the future, while older residents looked back to a harsher past to find hope.
item.dc:creator: Amy Chang Chien, John Liu and Paul Mozur
item.media:credit: An Rong Xu for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers cleaned up a beach on the Matsu Islands on Thursday as Taiwanese troops loaded artillery shells onto a boat. Life there has proceeded mostly as normal during China’s recent military drills.

item.title: The Mysterious Dance of the Cricket Embryos
item.description: A team of biologists and mathematicians studied hours of video to learn how insects take shape in the egg. The secret is geometry.
item.dc:creator: Siobhan Roberts
item.media:credit: Mustafa Hussain for The New York Times

item.title: Who Killed Tair Rada? Inside Israel’s True Crime Obsession
item.description: A TV documentary upended a murder case and captivated the nation. But its sensational theories might also be distorting justice.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Margalit

item.title: How Republicans Are ‘Weaponizing’ Public Office Against Climate Action
item.description: A Times investigation revealed a coordinated effort by state treasurers to use government muscle and public funds to punish companies trying to reduce greenhouse gases.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:credit: Kristian Thacker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Riley Moore, the West Virginia treasurer, announced last week that several major banks would be barred from government contracts with his state.

item.title: Vladimir Putin and Tayyip Erdogan Meet in Sochi
item.description: The Turkish and Russian leaders sat face-to-face for the second time in less than three weeks, solidifying Turkey’s role as a bridge to the West and a mediator between Russia and Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Turkish Presidential Press Service, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo released by the Turkish Presidential Press Service showed Recep Tayyip Erdogan and his Russian counterpart, President Vladimir V. Putin, in Sochi, Russia, on Friday.

item.title: Ukrainian First Lady Raises $5.4 Million for New Ambulances
item.description: Olena Zelenska has recently become more visible in advocating for humanitarian causes.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A wounded Ukrainian soldier being transferred from the front lines near Izium, eastern Ukraine, to a hospital in the city of Kramatorsk in June.

item.title: Three More Grain Ships Have Been Cleared to Leave Ukraine
item.description: The ships are carrying a total of about 64,000 tons of corn from Ukraine’s desperately needed stores.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Sophie Downes
item.media:description: The Navi-Star waiting to depart with its cargo of grain at the Port of Odesa in Ukraine last week.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Russia Sentences Brittney Griner to 9 Years
item.description: Also, China’s military tests threaten Taiwan and Australia advances a major climate bill.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: U.S. basketball player Brittney Griner stood in a defendants' cage in Khimki, outside Moscow, on August 4, 2022.

item.title: Russian Court Sentences Griner to 9 Years in a Penal Colony
item.description: Amid the hostility over the war in Ukraine, a court imposed nearly the maximum possible sentence on the American basketball star Brittney Griner, intensifying calls to win her release.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:description: Brittney Griner leaving the courtroom before the court's final decision in Khimki outside Moscow on Thursday.

item.title: A Large Object Landed on His Sheep Farm. It Came From Space.
item.description: “It’s not something you see every day on a sheep farm,” a farmer said of the pieces of debris that wound up in rural Australia. They are thought to be from a SpaceX spacecraft.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Jenny Gross
item.media:description: A sheepherder in Dalgety, Australia, stumbled upon a tall piece of space junk, said to be debris from the SpaceX Crew-1 spacecraft.

item.title: Tourists Are Injured Near Icelandic Volcanic Eruption
item.description: The injuries were not serious, but they underscored the risks facing tourists who hike to the Fagradalsfjall volcano in southwest Iceland, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: The Fagradalsfjall volcano has been drawing tourists, despite warnings from the government that the area is dangerous.

item.title: Hockey Canada to Be Investigated After Settling Sexual Assault Complaints
item.description: Canada’s governing body for hockey has come under increasing scrutiny after revelations that it has paid millions of dollars to settle sexual assault and abuse claims.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Sean Kilpatrick/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: From left, Andrew Winton, a lawyer, Scott Smith, the president of Hockey Canada, and Brian Cairo, the group’s chief financial officer, appeared before a parliamentary committee looking into how Hockey Canada handled sexual assault allegations

item.title: Griner Will Be Sent to a Russian Penal Colony. What Does That Mean?
item.description: The penal colonies, many of them scattered across Siberia, are descendants of gulags and are characterized by brutality, overcrowding and harsh conditions.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:description: Penal colony IK-3, in Vladimir, Russia, one of the detention centers where opposition leader Aleksei Navalny has reportedly been held during his imprisonment.

item.title: With 5 Missiles, China Sends Stark Signal to Japan and U.S. on Taiwan
item.description: By firing into Japanese waters, Beijing is warning that both countries will become targets if they should come to the aid of Taiwan in any conflict.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley
item.media:description: This photograph released by the People’s Liberation Army of China purports to show conventional missiles being test fired into waters off the east coast of Taiwan from an undisclosed location in China.

item.title: As Monkeypox Spreads, U.S. Declares a Health Emergency
item.description: The designation will free up emergency funds and lift some bureaucratic hurdles, but many experts fear containment may no longer be possible.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: A monkeypox vaccination at a clinic on Fire Island in New York this month. As of Wednesday, the United States had recorded nearly 7,000 monkeypox cases.

item.title: Who Is Viktor Bout, Russian Arms Dealer Who Could Be Involved in Griner Trade?
item.description: The United States has proposed exchanging Brittney Griner and another American jailed in Russia for Mr. Bout, who was convicted in 2011 on charges including conspiring to kill American citizens.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: The United States has proposed exchanging Viktor Bout, an imprisoned Russian arms dealer, for Brittney Griner and Paul Whelan, a former Marine.

item.title: ‘I Made an Honest Mistake,’ Brittney Griner Tells The Court
item.description: Brittney Griner offered a glimpse of her personal story while testifying in a Russian court on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Brittney Griner speaking with her lawyers Maria Blagovolina, left, and Alexander Boykov in court on Thursday.

item.title: U.S. Bolsters Aid for Cambodia Amid Efforts to Ease Global Food Crisis
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken announced $25 million over five years to support an initiative that will work with farmers and others in the agriculture industry to get produce to more markets.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.media:description: Selling fish near the Mekong River in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, on Tuesday. The problem of global food insecurity has become more pressing since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: Irish Farmers Help Save a Bird Whose Calls Used to Herald Summer
item.description: The corncrake’s cry, thought to be loud and harsh, is a poignant reminder for older people of the advent of warmer weather. Efforts are underway to preserve its call for younger generations.
item.dc:creator: Ed O’Loughlin
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: John Carey, the director of Corncrake Life, a conservation effort created to increase the birds’ population, with Margaret Gaughan, a farmer participating in the project, in Belmullet, Ireland.

item.title: Germany’s conservative leaders push for nuclear power to stay on as the country breaks from Russian fuels.
item.description: Nuclear power is contentious in Germany, but the country is also likely to be sharply affected by Europe’s efforts to wean itself off Russian fuel sources because of Moscow’s war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: The German village of Wattenbacherau, at the foot of the Isar 2 nuclear power plant, last week.

item.title: Defying the Supreme Court
item.description: The Kansas abortion vote and the congressional push on same-sex marriage show how progressives can confront the Supreme Court.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: A view of the U.S. Capitol from the Supreme Court.

item.title: U.S. to give Cambodia $25 million in agriculture aid.
item.description: Antony J. Blinken also called the Turkish foreign minister and praised his efforts in helping get Russia to allow food shipments to leave Ukrainian ports.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, center, touring food businesses at the AmCam Exchange on Thursday in Phnom Penh, Cambodia.

item.title: Russia’s Shortfalls Create an Opportunity for Ukraine, Western Officials Say
item.description: Severe equipment and manpower problems could slow President Vladimir V. Putin’s mission as the war enters its sixth month.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has shown no indications that he wants any sort of full-scale draft, despite setbacks in Ukraine.

item.title: Long a Climate Straggler, Australia Advances a Major Bill to Cut Emissions
item.description: Experts said the pledge to reduce emissions by at least 43 percent from 2005 levels by 2030 was both a leap forward and a first step.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Australia is one of the most vulnerable countries to the ravages of climate change.

item.title: Brittney Griner’s trial nears an end with closing arguments.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Guards escorting Brittney Griner to her court hearing in Khimki, outside Moscow, on Thursday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Taiwan braces for Chinese drills.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: A news broadcast in Beijing showed where China will hold military drills off Taiwan.

item.title: When Home Is a Ferry Ship: An Influx From Ukraine Strains Europe
item.description: Millions have fled Russia’s invasion, but where housing is expensive and scarce, countries like Estonia are paying shipping firms to offer refugees safe but tight quarters.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Marta Giaccone for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lunch time aboard the Isabelle cruise ship, which temporary houses 1,900 Ukrainians.

item.title: Chinese Missiles Strike Seas Off Taiwan, and Some Land Near Japan
item.description: A day after Nancy Pelosi’s trip, China has begun military drills near Taiwan. They appear to be designed as a trial run for sealing off the island. Five missiles landed in Japanese waters.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Amy Chang Chien, Eric Schmitt and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: Chinese military helicopters off the shore of Fujian Province, just across the strait from Taiwan, on Thursday.

item.title: Senate Overwhelmingly Votes to Add Sweden and Finland to NATO
item.description: The lopsided bipartisan vote demonstrated broad support in the United States for one of the most significant expansions of the military alliance, amid Russia’s continued assault on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Senate voted to ratify the expansion of NATO.

item.title: As China Plans Drills Circling Taiwan, U.S. Officials Fear a Squeeze Play
item.description: Administration officials say they are hoping China’s military exercises last only a few days, but they are discussing their options if the movements expand into something more.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Amy Qin
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Taiwanese military participating in a military exercise in Pingtung, Taiwan, last month.

item.title: The U.N. secretary general slams oil companies for ‘grotesque greed.’
item.description: António Guterres said the world was facing an energy crisis sparked by the war in Ukraine and called on governments to tax oil companies’ profits and distribute the proceeds to the poor.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: António Guterres, the United Nations secretary general, spoke to reporters at the U.N. headquarters in New York on Wednesday.

item.title: Switzerland, Leader in Gold Refining, Bans Import of Russian Gold
item.description: The move follows similar bans by the European Union and the United States.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai

item.title: Welcomed by Taiwan, Pelosi Leaves Rising Tensions With China in Her Wake
item.description: In a high-stakes visit to Taiwan, Ms. Pelosi offered assurances of American support. Taiwan now faces the prospect of Chinese military drills that could violate what it says are its territorial waters.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur, Amy Chang Chien, John Liu and Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi visiting Taiwan’s legislature in Taipei on Wednesday.

item.title: Ukraine Builds a Case That Killing of P.O.W.s Was a Russian War Crime
item.description: At a Russian-held prison, graves were dug days before the explosion that killed at least 50 Ukrainian troops held there, Ukrainian officials said.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Christiaan Triebert, Kamila Hrabchuk and Stanislav Kozliuk
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Tensions Rise as Pelosi Leaves Taiwan
item.description: Also, Ukraine braces for a Russian attack and Mexico faces an extreme drought.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: Nancy Pelosi, the speaker of the House, met with Taiwan’s president, Tsai Ing-wen, and was presented with an award for outstanding contributions to Taiwan.

item.title: U.S. Senate Votes to Accept Sweden and Finland in NATO
item.description: The move drew broad bipartisan support, as many Republicans break from former President Donald J. Trump’s ‘America first’ approach.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: Senator Chuck Schumer speaking with Ambassador Karin Olofsdotter of Sweden, center, and Paivi Nevala, a Finnish diplomat, at the Capitol on Wednesday.
